title: Education programmes for people with chronic kidney disease and diabetes
authors: Cashmore, BA; Cooper, TE; Evangelidis, NM; Green, SC; Lopez-Vargas, P; Tunnicliffe, DJ

response.output:
Education programmes for people with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and diabetes

People with CKD and diabetes often have poor adherence to their treatment regimens, which can lead to complications and reduced quality of life. Education programmes can help improve adherence by providing intensive education and behavioural counselling.

What do people with CKD and diabetes need to know?

To manage their condition effectively, people with CKD and diabetes need to know about their disease, medication schedules, dietary recommendations, blood glucose monitoring, and kidney function monitoring.

What did we find?

We evaluated the benefits and harms of education programmes for people with CKD and diabetes. Our results show that education programmes probably lower glycated haemoglobin (HbA1c) in people with CKD and diabetes (large effect, moderate certainty).

What does this mean?

Education programmes may improve knowledge of some areas related to diabetes care and some self-management practices. Education programmes probably decrease HbA1c in people with CKD and diabetes, but the effect on other clinical outcomes is unclear.

Limitations

We have little confidence in the evidence because it is possible that people in the studies were aware of which treatment they were getting, and because the studies were very small.

What are the implications of this review?

More randomised studies are needed to examine the efficacy of education programmes on important clinical outcomes in people with CKD and diabetes.
